summary: Build a simple, stable Word-to-PDF conversion tool using a Node.js backend with LibreOffice headless, plus a minimal frontend upload/convert/download UI (no pdfMake or unstable CDNs).
architectural_notes: Do not rely on unstable CDN libraries; prefer local dependencies.
Backend: Node.js service handles .docx upload, converts to PDF using LibreOffice in headless mode, returns downloadable PDF.
known_issues: Existing Word-to-PDF implementation is broken with errors: "PDF library failed to initialize" and "pdfMake failed to load".

existing_features.title: Completely remove the existing client-side Word-to-PDF implementation and all pdfMake initialization/loading logic so the app no longer attempts to load pdfMake (including CDN scripts) or shows errors like "PDF library failed to initialize" / "pdfMake failed to load".

Rebuild the Word-to-PDF tool frontend as a simple 3-step UI (Upload Word file → Convert → Download PDF) using only stable, locally-bundled code (no CDN-loaded libraries). The UI must: show selected file name, show a loading indicator while converting, show a success message after conversion, use a clean visible green primary button, disable the Convert button while processing, and avoid confusing messages.

Implement strict file validation for the Word-to-PDF tool: accept only .docx files, enforce a 10MB maximum file size, and show a clear English error message when the file type or file size is invalid.
Add a backend-based Word-to-PDF conversion API that accepts an uploaded .docx and returns a downloadable PDF, and wire the frontend Convert action to call this backend API.

Remove or update any tool metadata, copy, and UX that claims Word-to-PDF conversion happens “in your browser” and ensure the Word-to-PDF page content matches the new backend-based flow (still keeping messages simple and non-confusing).

new_feature_requests.summary: Rebuild Word-to-PDF tool from scratch: Node.js backend upload .docx (10MB max), convert via LibreOffice headless, return downloadable PDF; minimal frontend with file name, loading state, success/error messaging, and disabled convert button while processing (no pdfMake/CDN libs).
